Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks funding to continue the neutron monitor observations at McMurdo for at least 4 years of operation - through the next solar activity maximum predicted in 2011-12. The neutron monitor in McMurdo is a crucial element of the "Spaceship Earth" array - a 12-station multi-national network of neutron monitors optimized to measure the angular distribution of relativistic solar cosmic rays. McMurdo has the southernmost viewing direction of any neutron monitor station in the World, thereby providing a critical three-dimensional perspective on the cosmic ray distribution measured by the global array. Data returned from McMurdo and other "Spaceship Earth" stations will enable the advanced understanding of the acceleration and transport of solar energetic particles, and of the transient and long-term modulation of galactic cosmic rays by the Sun. From the historical occurrence rates, continuing McMurdo observations through the solar activity maximum would allow to detect new relativistic solar particle events. Neutron monitors can play a direct role in forecasting and specifying solar wind disturbances, thus improving the capability to forecast major space weather events for the societal benefit. For example, providing the cosmic rays Ground-Level Enhancement (GLE) alerts is of direct relevance to aviation flights over high latitudes where these events can pose health hazards.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Radiation is something we live with every day. It comes from outer space and from the rocks around us, from bricks, concrete, and so forth. A neutron monitor measures secondary neutrons that are byproducts of primary cosmic rays that impact Earth and collide with molecules in EarthÆs atmosphere. At the same time, the neutron monitorÆs ingenious design permits it to screen out environmental neutrons from terrestrial sources, so the neutron monitor count rate provides a remarkably accurate measure of the intensity of cosmic rays striking Earth at a particular location. This project supported continued operation of a neutron monitor in McMurdo, Antarctica that made its first measurements in 1960. One outcome of this project was a retrospective analysis of the Ground Level Enhancement (GLE) of January 20, 2005. GLEs occur when the Sun emits energetic particles of sufficient energy and intensity to raise radiation levels at EarthÆs surface. They occur at a typical rate of about 15 events per 11-year solar cycle. The January 20, 2005 GLE was the second largest observed since systematic measurements commenced in 1936, with up to 4200% count rate enhancement (relative to the pre-event Galactic cosmic ray background) at sea level. In our analysis we used McMurdo data in concert with other high-latitude neutron monitors to derive the time evolution of the density, anisotropy, pitch angle distribution, and energy spectrum of the relativistic solar particles at 1-min time resolution. One remarkable aspect of the event was the extremely large anisotropy, with a peak maximum-to-minimum ratio of the directional intensity over 1000:1. Future analyses will use these detailed measurements to numerically model the event in order to obtain new information on the acceleration of particles at the Sun, and on the mechanism of particle scattering by magnetic turbulence in the interplanetary medium. Solar modulation of cosmic rays refers to the process by which the Sun and solar wind alter the intensity and energy of Galactic cosmic rays entering the solar system. The second major outcome of this project was to show that the modulated intensity of Galactic cosmic rays reached a new record high 3% above the previous record during the recent unusual solar minimum. To reach a consistent result, we found it necessary to remove systematic trends of unknown origin from the data time series of the neutron monitors considered. By combining data from monitors at different geomagnetic cutoffs, we were also able to derive the spectrum of the "extra" particles present during the cosmic ray maximum of 2009. The mysterious downtrend in South Pole neutron monitor count rates has continued through the recent record maximum in the modulated intensity of Galactic cosmic rays. McMurdo data played a key role in reaching this conclusion, because they permitted a careful internormalization of Pole data from November 2005, when the Pole monitor was deactivated, to the time of its reactivation in February 2010. We speculate that the South Pole trend may reflect a true change in the radiation environment at Pole caused by secular changes in the geomagnetic field, but it remains for future research to determine whether this is in fact the source of the South Pole decline.
